chapter.title: Hidden disabilities
chapter.content:
Hidden disabilities

In effect, LD are hidden disabilities. They do not become apparent until individuals attempt tasks that are affected by their LD. As long as the individual can avoid tasks such as reading, math calculation, or math problem solving, the disability is not apparent.

chapter.title: Office of Special Education: SLD Initiative
chapter.content:
Office of Special Education: SLD Initiative

The best and most current guidance we have on the definition of LD is based on work done by the U.S. Department of Education. In 1999, the Office of Special Education Programs within the department began what was called the SLD Initiative. SLD stands for “specific learning disabilities.”

As part of this initiative, a group of 10 organizations was convened, representing parents, employers, state and local practitioners, researchers and policy developers, and individuals with LD, representing perspectives from Postsecondary, Vocational, and K-12 School settings. These groups were asked to develop consensus statements about the nature of LD. 

 

SLD Initiative
Groups Settings

chapter.title: Consensus definition of SLD
chapter.content:
Consensus definition of SLD

The SLD initiative involved a series of meetings and papers, and the development of a research-to-practice document. The group provided an overall statement defining LD. Let’s look at the consensus definition.

“Strong converging evidence supports the validity of the concept of SLD (specific learning disabilities). This evidence is particularly impressive because it converges across different indicators and methodologies. The central concept of SLD involves disorders of learning and cognition that are intrinsic to the individual. SLD are specific in the sense that these disorders each significantly affect a relatively narrow range of academic and performance outcomes. SLD may occur in combination with other disabling conditions, but they are not due primarily to other conditions, such as mental retardation, behavioral disturbance, lack of opportunities to learn, or primary sensory deficits.”

Consider for a moment, what are some major points in this consensus definition? When you are done with your reflections, please click the forward arrow for some key points.

chapter.title: Key points of consensus SLD definition
chapter.content:
Key points of consensus SLD definition

During your reflections, you may have drawn main points similar to these:

  • LD is a valid concept.
  • There is convincing evidence to support this condition.
  • It is a disability that affects learning and cognition.
  • It is based on conditions within individuals.
  • It affects specific academic and functional tasks.
  • It is possible to have LD with other conditions, but those conditions are not the cause for the LD.

Please note that the consensus definition uses the term “specific learning disabilities,” or SLD. In this Learning to Achieve program, however, we will consistently refer to specific learning disabilities as learning disabilities, or LD.

chapter.title: Contributors to the LD definition controversy and debate
chapter.content:
Contributors to the LD definition controversy and debate

There has been and continues to be controversy and debate in the field over how to define LD. The reasons for the controversy are complex, and include the following.

  • LD cannot be easily observed.
  • How LD are defined affects funding for many different organizations.
  • How LD are defined affects access to services for many different individuals.
  • The field’s understanding of LD has changed over time.

While all of these issues contribute to the controversy and debate over the definition of LD, it is particularly important to note  the first reason— learning disabilities cannot be easily observed. Click the forward arrow to find out why this is the case.
